oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Billy Sherrill Interviewed by Bob Allen in 1982 Side Two
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of Billy Sherrill being interviewed by Bob Allen. The interview takes place on 12-22-82.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Billy Sherrill
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side Two - (0:15) -- Billy Sherrill discusses working with Peanutt Montgomery. (1:28) -- Bob Allen asks about recording with only 8 tracks. Billy Sherrill speaks about recording drums before anything else. (2:38) -- Billy Sherrill discusses scratching a vinyl record to produce a homemade metronome/drummer. He calculated the scratches with a compass. "It's called survival, not being able to pay a drummer." - Billy Sherrill. (4:25) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about almost getting fired over EQ'ing a song. (6:12) -- Bob Allen asks Billy Sherrill about his new producing techniques. Bob Allen mentions the complexity of Billy Sherrill's string recording. (7:16) -- Billy Sherrill mentions the influence of Johann Strauss on his string arrangements. (7:58) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about altering the waltz beat on the song "Almost Persuaded." (9:43) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about asking the musicians to physically change their instrument dynamics when recording. (12:30) -- Bob Allen asks about Billy Sherrill's use of steel guitar. Billy Sherrill mentions pop stations giving him feedback to replace steel guitar with a horn section. (16:50) -- "I can go back and listen to a record I did ten years ago and I'm ashamed of it. I can see things I'd wish I had done." - Billy Sherrill discusses the advancements in recording technologies in the past ten years. Billy Sherrill mentions that this newer recording technology creates a desire to go back and change records he made in the past. (18:35) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about the release of 16-track recording. He mentions that producers were eager to fill up more than 8 tracks just because they had the new ability to do so. (21:14) -- "A lot of times less is best." - Billy Sherrill. Billy Sherrill goes on to describe Merle Haggard's minimalistic approach to recording. (22:35) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about regretting the mix on Charlie Rich's "The Most Beautiful Girl." (24:46) -- Billy Sherrill discusses the negative recording impact of using over 24-tracks. (26:11) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about Floyd Cramer's piano lick on "Last Date." Billy Sherrill used this pedal effect on the song "Behind Closed Doors" by Charlie Rich. (28:45) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about his recording work with Tammy Wynette. (29:49) -- Bob Allen asks about the arrangement of "Stand By Your Man" by Tammy Wynette. (35:52) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about receiving feedback from the Epic/CBS New York A&R Department. (37:00) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about using a two octave gliss, "Yeah but that was all the way from Nashville to Heaven, see, it had to be a long gliss" - Billy Sherrill. (37:19) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about how the use of strings can be abused. (40:12) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about the gospel roots of the Statler Brothers and The Oak Ridge Boys. (40:58) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about his budget when producing for CBS. (41:41) -- Billy Sherrill speaks about recording Barbara Mandrell's "The Midnight Oil." Billy Sherrill slowed a track down to 7 1/2 inches per second and recorded a tack piano. Sherrill then increased the speed back to 15 IPS in order to achieve the sound of a mandolin on the recording.
